block.p: Tire Used as Replacement By Ford to Be Investigated One model of tire that Ford is using to replace Firestone Wilderness AT's has a higher rate of damage claims than the Firestones do, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said as it opened a defect inquiry into the tire.

The tire, the General Ameri*550 AS, made by Continental, has caused seven crashes with 17 injuries, the traffic safety agency said. But it cautioned that the inquiry did not mean the tires were not safe. [Page C2.]

Qualcomm Cancels Spinoff of Unit Qualcomm, the mobile phone technology company, canceled plans to spin off its semiconductor division and said that its president and chief operating officer, Richard Sulpizio, had resigned. The company announced that it would restructure itself under a shuffled management team. Shares of Qualcomm fell $3.10, or 5 percent, to $57.75. [C4.]
Fed Chief Says Cuts Are Working Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that interest rate cuts were having their desired effect on the economy. [C6.]

Quick Power Fixes for New York The future of electricity is arriving in New York this summer as a jumble of schemes and mechanisms. Utility companies, the state government, businesses and consumers are each cranking up their own quick fixes. [A1.]

Novel Contract Offered to Pilots American Airlines offered its pilots a novel contract: a pay raise of 15 percent to 22 percent in exchange for a shorter negotiating period followed by binding arbitration. [C2.]

Steeped in Family and Faith J. W. Marriott Jr. says his family and his faith are the most important things in his life; both seem to have had a strong influence on his leadership of Marriott International. ''I devote Saturday to my family and Sunday to my church,'' he said. ''When people ask me what's your greatest disappointment, I say I never learned how to play golf. My greatest accomplishment is my family.'' The Boss. [C8.]
Honeywell Profit Declines 92% Honeywell International said that its second-quarter earnings plunged 92 percent, but the results surpassed expectations. [C10.]
ABB Plans to Eliminate 12,000 Jobs ABB, the electrical engineering group, posted a 21 percent drop in half-year profit. It plans to shed 12,000 jobs. [World Business, Section W.]
